G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limit of the District Court and the property in question is located in Brockton, Massachusetts.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.190.proposition: As part of the lease agreement, Defendant was obligated to maintain the Premises in compliance with state and local housing laws, which include the provision of essential services such as hot water, a requirement under 105 C.M.R. § 410.190 of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every tenant is entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, meaning the right to use and enjoy leased premises free from serious interference by the landlord.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) – Enunciates tenant rights under the warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) – Enunciates tenant rights under the warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a concurrence/dissent, but it confirms that the court’s opinion (which Quirico partially joins and partially rejects) is announcing new rules about landlord obligations tied to habitability and the interdependence of rent and repair obligations. He explicitly acknowledges that the majority reverses the old common-law rule of no implied fitness and makes the landlord’s obligation to maintain habitable premises and the tenant’s rent obligation mutually interdependent. Although this passage does not itself elaborate the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the case as a whole is correctly cited for enunciating tenants’ rights under the warranty of habitability and related doctrines.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt:
“The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. That holding is sufficient to dispose of the only issues raised in these cases, and to that extent I concur with the opinion.
…
The second step required for the removal of the roadblock is the reversal of the present common law rule that the obligation of the tenant to pay rent and the obligation, if any, of the landlord to repair or maintain the rented premises are independent, and the substitution therefor of a new rule that such obligations are substantially mutually interdependent. The opinion of the court accomplishes this.”} RTWF```json```**Note**: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part. The majority opinion (not reproduced here) more directly articulates the implied warranty of habitability and its relationship to tenant rights and rent obligations. However, Quirico’s discussion confirms that the case indeed enunciates those tenant rights. Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) – Statutory remedies for breach of quiet enjoyment include damages.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) – Statutory remedies for breach of quiet enjoyment include damages.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The case does discuss the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the cited opinion passage focuses on liability and the availability of injunctive relief, costs, and attorney’s fees. It does not separately analyze or highlight a distinct category of "statutory remedies" for breach of quiet enjoyment, nor does it specifically frame the holding as clarifying that such remedies "include damages." While § 14 by its terms provides for damages, this decision is not used here as a clear authority for that particular remedial proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. This section also confers on the Superior and District Courts the authority in equity to restrain violations of its provisions. ... If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) \u.raw_text: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) – Consequential damages, including emotional distress, recoverable for breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) \u.proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) – Consequential damages, including emotional distress, recoverable for breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) \u.support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to allow recovery of “actual and consequential damages,” and then holds that this includes personal injuries such as emotional distress resulting from interference with quiet enjoyment. Although the court ultimately vacates the separate $10,000 quiet-enjoyment damages as duplicative, it squarely states that emotional distress damages are within the scope of consequential damages under § 14 and uses that conclusion to uphold a substantial attorneys’ fee award tied to the quiet enjoyment claim.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) \u.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. … Generally, ‘actual damages’ are losses flowing directly from a wrongful act. … ‘Consequential damages’ cover all losses that are reasonably foreseeable to the actor… For example, consequential damages in an action based on contract or warranty may include personal injuries caused by the breach. … The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).raw_text: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) – Treble damages mandated for intentional or reckless landlord interference.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) – Treble damages mandated for intentional or reckless landlord interference.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not address, much less decide, that treble damages are mandated for intentional or reckless landlord interference. Its discussion of treble damages appears only in describing the separate lead paint statute (G.L. c. 111, § 199), not as an interpretation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. The holding of Al‑Ziab concerns the fault level (at least negligence) required for quiet enjoyment liability and the non‑availability of attorney’s fees via § 14 for mere strict liability lead paint violations, not a mandate of treble damages for intentional or reckless interference under § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 111, §§ 190-199…imposes strict liability on landlords for damages caused by poisoning from lead paint, and provides for treble damages if a landlord has been notified of the presence of lead paint and fails to correct it as provided by the statute. G. L. c. 111, § 199. … Significantly, the statute makes no provision for the payment of attorney’s fees… Were we to accept the plaintiffs’ argument, all landlords held strictly liable under the lead paint statute would necessarily be required to pay the attorney’s fees of the tenant. That result is inconsistent with the statutory scheme….”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.raw_text: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) – Breach of quiet enjoyment does not require malicious intent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) – Breach of quiet enjoyment does not require malicious intent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that prior cases requiring intent are not controlling and that it is the landlord’s conduct, not intent, that governs breach of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that a breach can occur where the disturbing condition is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do, even though the landlord did not intend to violate the tenant’s rights. This directly supports the proposition that a breach of quiet enjoyment does not require malicious or intentional conduct.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment… Although some of our opinions have spoken of… a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006).raw_text: Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006) – Essential services like hot water are part of habitability standards.
Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006).proposition: Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006) – Essential services like hot water are part of habitability standards.
Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006).case_name: Cote-Whitacre v. Department of Public Health
Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006).support_reasoning: The provided opinion text concerns procedural rulings related to same-sex marriage recognition for residents of various states and does not address landlord-tenant law, habitability, or essential services such as hot water. There is nothing in this decision about standards of habitability or essential services, so it cannot support the claimed proposition. The citation is therefore inaccurate or misplaced for that legal principle.
Armstrong v. Ward, 446 Mass. 376 (2006).relevant_excerpt: The orders denying the plaintiffs’ motions for preliminary injunction in these cases are affirmed. A majority of the Justices also agree that, as to the plaintiffs who reside in Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont, a judgment for the defendants shall enter in the Superior Court because same-sex marriage is prohibited in those States. As to the New York and Rhode Island plaintiffs, their cases shall proceed in the Superior Court, on an expedited basis, for a determination whether same-sex marriage is prohibited in those States.

Lashley v. Horton, 325 Mass. 121 (1949).raw_text: Lashley v. Horton, 325 Mass. 121 (1949) – Housing violations create liability for interference with tenant enjoyment.
Lashley v. Horton, 325 Mass. 121 (1949).proposition: Lashley v. Horton, 325 Mass. 121 (1949) – Housing violations create liability for interference with tenant enjoyment.
Lashley v. Horton, 325 Mass. 121 (1949).support_reasoning: The opinion in Lashley v. Horton is an insurance misrepresentation case about an accident and health policy; it does not concern landlord-tenant law, housing code violations, or interference with a tenant’s enjoyment of premises. Nothing in the reasoning or holding discusses housing violations or creates liability on that basis. The proposition attributed to this case is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion.
Lashley v. Horton, 325 Mass. 121 (1949).relevant_excerpt: This is an action of contract upon a policy of accident and health insurance, issued on June 20, 1931, to recover for total disability occurring in 1941, as the result, the plaintiff contends, of a coronary heart attack. The existence, but not the cause, of total disability was admitted. The answer contains a general denial, and alleges that the policy never took effect both because the plaintiff, with actual intent to deceive, made certain false representations in his application, and because the false representations increased the risk of loss.
